ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned much about my Vietnamese history, and I especially loved the folktales unit
A deeper understanding of Vietnamese culture and literature, with a heavy focus in the last half on the Vietnamese War

I learned how to analyze Vietnamese literature critically, write concisely, and understand major themes in Viet lit such as displacement, war, love, sexuality, family, and many other cultural values. I also got to watch Vietnamese films, listen to some Vietnamese songs, and improve on my Vietnamese reading skills as well (although all of the texts are translated to English, it was nice to also be given the original versions).
enjoyed some Vietnamese classics, films, music, and learned from panelists and speaker event
I learned more about Vietnamese culture through poetry, short stories, and music.
I learned a lot about Vietnamese culture and history, and how to analyze and connect the themes seen in different readings together.
I learned about Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American literature, poetry, movies, and history.

I developed a holistic understanding of Vietnamese culture starting from foundational myths through modern movements. Our discussions often revolved around literature in various forms like myths, poems, and books.

I developed a much deeper understanding of Vietnamese culture, values, and literature. In addition to learning about the impact of the Vietnam War on Vietnamese civilians and refugees, I also learned both about traditional and modern/ contemporary Vietnamese literature and pop culture in this course.
Developed insight into Vietnamese culture and background information on the history of the country.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Professor Van is so kind, and it is so important to have more POC professors at Yale to empower under-represented students!
Weakness: the lectures were not that stimulating to me, a regurgitation of what we read

Strengths: really good readings and guest speakers, grader was also great
Weaknesses: Sometimes, presentations felt a bit disorganized, and a lot of materials or assignments were uploaded to canvas late. Awkward silences tended to linger

Strengths: Professor Van is very smart and kind. His insights into Vietnamese literature was a joy to listen to, and it was also great to hear other Vietnamese and non-Vietnamese students give input into the readings.

Weakness: The larger size of the class at times made it seem intimidating to speak in.

strength - strong and interesting syllabus, even when there were changes made throughout the semester. reflection papers were a good way to think about the syllabus materials, but i would like it better if it was a public Canvas discussion post where we could learn from each other. perhaps the students can be split in half where one group is responsible for responding to posts, while the other half writes the post, since there's not enough discussion going on in class because no one feels comfortable enough to do so, but everyone has plenty of personal reflections about the material

weakness - it doesn't look like the Prof has updated his slides from when he first started teaching this course, so it's much less engaging because it feels outdated. he does not have presentations for the newer materials on the syllabus. overall the presentation of material would be more engaging if the Prof provided analyses or shared significance of the readings or films we watched. he tried to drive the conversation in class by asking questions to students, but it's much better if he started with an interesting interpretation/argument of a piece and asked for our thoughts. sometimes he would ask leading questions and there would not be room for students to share their own thoughts; he seemed to be searching for a 'right' answer when it should be better for there to be room for discussion and open interpretation. the Prof had many opportunities to lecture about vietnamese literature and culture in a more meaningful, perhaps emotional/personal way as there are Vietnamese students in the class too who would benefit from greater depth of the material, but he ended up allowing the poetry speaker event and the vietnamese american speaker panel at the end of the course to deal with that. would be interesting if the class discussion topics could be more student driven based on student interest - maybe even having the speaker panels at the beginning of the course for students to get an overview about what is meant by the 'vietnamese' experience
I wish we had more opportunities for smaller group discussions. Especially during the first half of the course, most of the classes would be Professor Van lecturing for 1 hour +.

The class is very poorly structured in that there is no clear expectation for assignments and the class would never follow the syllabus, making it hard to expect what we should be doing for homework until the professor posts the assignment the day before it is due. Because of the lack of structure, I found that it was harder to engage with the material.

The course has some excellent readings and Thay Quang is an incredible man. I think more discussion-based learning would have been nice, perhaps individual presentations. Also, having a more defined and specific syllabus at the beginning of the course would be helpful.
Great professor

I loved how the course allowed students to choose when and what to write reflection papers on. This made me feel like the connection I made with the material was very genuine. I also appreciated the flexibility of the final project and the guest speakers.

One of the strengths of this course were that Thay Quang was extremely lenient in terms of the grading & due dates of the reflection papers to accommodate for the difficulties of this semester. On the same vein, Thay Quang allowed for a lot of flexibility in terms of what the reflection papers discussed and what the final project was. Students in this course were thus able to explore a lot in regards to what interested them and intrigued them in this course, and the resulting final projects were very varied and unique (translation projects on V-pop songs, Viet food tours, children's books, etc.). Another strength was that Thay Quang was also willing to change the class schedule if he found that another topic was more important to discuss. In doing so, he integrated a lot of ViSA events and movie screenings into the class schedule, and that made it so that there were more forms of engagement and discussion in the class. Of course, this did mean that ultimately there were some things in the syllabus that we were not able to cover and/or spend much time discussing, so that may be a weakness of the course.

Strengths: Prof. Van is great and often brings in very interesting guest speakers.  Very approachable workload.

Weaknesses:  Reading load is pretty high but not very necessary at the same time.  This definitely caused the readings to take a spot on the back burner a lot of the time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Succeed: great speakers
Improve: more stimulating lectures

Succeeded: Asynchronous classes worked really well with the online format (usually we would watch a movie and then prepare to discuss it in the next online lecture). Also having a lot of speakers come and speak with us via Zoom added a lot to the course.

Improved: More open and frequent communication with students about the reflection papers, due dates, and class plans.
need more breakout rooms, more ways for students to hear from each other rather than just from the professor

Instead of having just readings that may wear out the student, the course brought in a variety of different sources such as films, readings, and guest speakers to keep the students engaged in the topic. I really liked the guest speakers as they provided a real perspective of what we have been learning about in class.
The professor was incredibly understanding with assignments and the challenges of the semester. Overall, virtual learning is very limited and should not be used any more than absolutely necessary.
I think the flexibility in the reflection papers really helped with covid.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Vietnamese history is so much more than the Vietnam War, and all students should take the course with professor Van
Yes, the course offers an alternative to western perspectives and it does so really nicely
Absolutely! I think this class would work great in-person. I think everyone who took this class was very open and thoughtful, and if you're Viet you can also meet other Vietnamese Yalies.

while Vietnamese literature, culture, and values is a wonderful topic, the class is too disorganized, and it may be best to explore the topics on your own time and nurture your personal interest. however, it can be a friendly starting place if you just want an intro to Vietnamese ways of thinking, but it will be shallow
If you want to learn more about Vietnamese culture and read Vietnamese literature, then yes!

I would recommend this course to another student that is looking for an easy and fun humanities credit. The workload for this course is pretty light, but the material that is being presented is very interesting so you get to learn a lot without having put in too much work for the class.

I would recommend the course to anyone looking to learn more about Vietnamese history and culture as well as presence in America. The students are also great people to learn from and there are many opportunities to engage with the material out of class as well.
Yes! Its a great course, and youll learn a lot about Vietnamese literature. Its easily accessible to non-Viet students too!

Yes. I feel like Vietnams culture provides a wide array of circumstances and perspectives for anyone to learn from. The class is well formatted for every student to choose what topics they want to invest in and connect with.

I would definitely recommend this course to students looking to learn more about Vietnam, regardless of whether or not they are Vietnamese. No Vietnam or Vietnamese knowledge is required for this course at all, and Thay Quang is accommodating of everyone.
Yes--especially if you are interested in Vietnamese culture.  Otherwise, I don't see why you would want to take it.  It provides exactly what it describes and more.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
A lot of the course was more lecture-based too
The class was ~25 students, so it was a combined live virtual lecture and virtual seminar.
We had virtual seminars that were sometimes recorded.
N/A
